utterances: And Bill Richardson too.
Who was accused of running for vice president during the debates itself.
But I mean, as been mentioned, I think, Edwards perhaps.
I mean, there was some speculation about maybe a turn in fortunes for Elizabeth Edwards regarding her health.
All right.
Thank you very much, Ken.
Stay with us.

We're going to be talking with Bill Carrick, who's a Democratic strategist, an ad producer; and later with Dan Schnur, a Republican strategist, about what happened yesterday and what it means to the future of the race.
I think that, perhaps, he may even want it.
I just suspect that they're going to look elsewhere.
Obama and Clinton will both look elsewhere.
But you know what is interesting?
We took about - only twice in history, has a United States senator, a sitting senator, ever been elected president - Warren Harding in 1920 and John Kennedy in 1960.
And it's a lock this time.
Well, we don't know if John McCain is a lock, but certainly, it would be among John McCain, Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama - the likelihood of a senator being elected president.
We always talk about governors.
It could be a senator this time.
And Erin, if an Obama-Edwards ticket is something that you're looking forward to, at least John Edwards doesn't have a job right now.
So he might be looking for work.
Oh, that's golden.
That is golden to me.
Now, how about Cabinet appointments for any of the other, like, earlier…
I think it's probably a little premature to think about Cabinet.
Well, it's not - because we've already announced that Bill Clinton as secretary of state, secretary of defense, United Nations ambassador and attorney general…
Right.
…so that's still - no, I'm kidding.
But look, Joe Biden's name have been mentioned.
Certainly, Bill Richardson's name have been mentioned.
And we always see in every presidential election that the president-elect does go to the Senate or the House for Cabinet appointees.
Erin, thanks very much for the call.
Appreciate it.
Thank you so much.
And the other news coming out of yesterday, that leaves two Democrats running for the presidential nomination - Senators Obama and Clinton.
Four Republicans remain.
We assume that Rudy Giuliani, after finishing third in Florida, forces him to announce his, not only withdrawal later today, but his endorsement expected of Senator John McCain.
But four Republicans remain in the race.
But John McCain, after his victory yesterday in Florida, looks very good.
Well, you know, the word frontrunner has been laughed at so many times.
First of all, we wrote, we, the media, the press, the candidates, the party establishment, all wrote off John McCain as early as - as recently as last summer.
He didn't have the staff.
He didn't have the money.
His views on immigration were in adamant to the party.
He had so many problems.
And yet, I mean, who knows what's going to happen February 5th, Super Tuesday, but we're all but anointing him as the Republican nominee, which is a remarkable comeback.
I mean, I don't know what's more remarkable.

The fact that Rudy Giuliani was the national frontrunner for the longest time, and he collapsed so quickly in the minds of the voters, or the fact that John McCain, who is left - written off for dead is now perhaps the Republican heir apparent.
The Lazarus act.
And in the meantime, you look at that election in Florida, this was a Republican primary, a closed primary.
Only Republicans could vote, only registered Republicans could vote.
Even so, John McCain managed to win in that primary election without winning the majority of the conservatives.
Right.
But let me say one thing about the Independents.

One reason that a lot of people thought that Mitt Romney was going to win Florida is that, unlike New Hampshire, unlike South Carolina, John McCain had Independents crossing over for him in those states.
And they helped propel him to victory.
Only Republicans could vote in the Florida primary, and yet McCain won anyway.
So it's very interesting.
But he still has the battle, you know, to go ahead among Republican conservatives with Mitt Romney.

Now perhaps with Rudy Giuliani getting out of the race, as we expected at 6 p.m. Eastern time today, there will be one person who might - I suspected Giuliani took away from McCain is both seen as kind of moderate wing of the party unlike the Romney-Huckabee wing of the party, which is more conservative.
So, perhaps Giuliani dropping out helps McCain.
But at some point, McCain is going to have to address the deficiencies many conservatives feel that they see in his candidacy.
So he's got fences to mend with the conservative wing of the party, the activist wing of the party, the people who are going to be there at his - if he's the nominee - at his convention.
In the meantime, Mitt Romney has to look ahead to a Super Tuesday field where he's competing against Mike Huckabee in a lot of Southern states and against John McCain, who got anointed today.
Yeah, I think Huckabee is left with the fact that what I once thought of he was, of course - he won Iowa.
He did very - he finished very strong second in South Carolina.
But he doesn't have much money.
Of course, McCain doesn't either.
But the more you win, the more money you get.
But Huckabee is looking at states like Tennessee, Georgia, Alabama on February 5th where the evangelical vote may still be potent.
But, for right now, for all intents and purposes many people feel this is a Romney versus McCain battle for the Republican nomination.
Okay and now we have some answers to the trivia question that had been called in to e-mail in.
This is from Aaron(ph) in Yardley, Pennsylvania.
Floridian who ran for president, George Smathers.
Well, that's the - I think that was the hardest one of the three.
But yes, George Smathers was a favorite-son candidate, a former John F.
Kennedy pal who died last year.
Smathers ran in 1960 and '68 as a favorite son.
Ian(ph) in Las Vegas suggests Lawton Chiles, Claude Pepper and Bob Graham.
We know one of them is right.
Well, Bob Graham definitely ran.
He was a presidential hopeful in 2004.
He dropped out early.
Lawton Chiles never ran for president.
No, he walked for president.
That's right.
He was the walking senator.
He walked the length of the state when he was elected senator in 1970.
He was a senator and governor of Florida.
He never ran for president.
And the third person mentioned was…
Claude Pepper.
Well, that's interesting.
Claude Pepper actually never ran, but he was the left-wing - he was the choice of the left-wing of the Democratic Party in 1947 - a faction that ultimately backed Henry Wallace.
They wanted Claude Pepper, but Claude Pepper never ran.
So we're missing one.
We have George Smathers.
We have Bob Graham.
We're missing one.
Well, Claude(ph) in Salem, Massachusetts suggests Bob Graham, Reubin Askew and Claude Pepper.
Of course, we'll have plenty of time for your calls.
There's so much news on the political front.
The Political Junkie is running the full hour today so stay with us.
If you'd like to join the conversation: 800-989-8255.
E-mail us -talk@npr.org.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
And before we get back to the Political Junkie, this news.
The Federal Reserve just reduced a key interest rate for the second time in just over a week.
It cut the federal funds rate by half a percent to 3 percent.
So we'll have more on that later today on NPR News.
Stay tuned for analysis of what that important stat means.
But - now let's get back to the Political Junkie.
This is the last time we have to talk before Super Tuesday, and we're just packed with news.
On the Republican side, former Mayor Rudy Giuliani's campaign is sputtering out.
He's expected to drop out later today and endorse Senator John McCain.
And former North Carolina Senator John Edwards announced about an hour ago that he would step aside in the Democratic race.
So what does all this means for the candidates who are left?
We've got NPR's political editor.
Our political junkie Ken Rudin with us today.
And, of course, you're invited to join the conversation.
E-mail: talk@npr.org.
And you can read what other listeners have to say on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.

And joining us now from NPR West in Culver City, California, is Democratic strategist Bill Carrick, a veteran of several presidential campaigns including those of Bill Clinton, Ted Kennedy and Richard Gephardt, not aligned with any candidate this year.
And Bill, it's nice to have you back on the program.
Great to be here.
And, I guess, the big news is John Edwards.
Why do you think he never got the traction that he hoped for?
I think, basically, that there wasn't room for him when both Senator Obama and Senator Clinton took off and, particularly when they started raising, you know, gargantuan amounts of money.
I just don't think Senator Edwards really had the wherewithal to compete with them, and there was just wasn't any oxygen left in the room for him.
Had either of their campaigns, for one reason or another, sputtered?
Do you think he might have had a chance then?
Yeah.
I think he still has high-approval ratings with Democratic voters.
I think his message was something that Democratic voters found very compatible.
He had a lot of devoted supporters, particularly in the labor movement.
And I think he could have been competitive in almost under any other circumstance.
It's just this time - the historic candidacy of Senator Clinton, the historic candidacy of Senator Obama, it just left very little for Senator Edwards to pick up.
And toward the end - the last few days, the last week or so - a lot of people thought, well, he could stay on.
Maybe take a kingmaker's role with a small - relatively small number of delegates that might be crucial at the Democratic convention.
You know, I think, once you decide that maybe you're not going to be able to get the nomination outright yourself.
Then the decision begins how long you want to stay in, how long you want to go through this.
You got to raise the money to sustain it.
Can you actually get over the 15 percent threshold you need to get delegates in every state?
He was able to do that in South Carolina.
Yesterday in Florida, even though, there weren't any delegates at stake, he got right at 15 percent.
So, I think, he was looking at a really tough road ahead.
And, I think, he made a very sound decision just - you know, it was time for him to get out and leave it to the other two candidates.
I think he made a very responsible decision.
